newsitem.title: INDIA: Cotton's share slipping in India fibre consumption.
newsitem.headline: Cotton's share slipping in India fibre consumption.

text.p: The share of cotton in India's total fibre consumption continues to fall though it is rising in quantitative terms, the Indian Cotton Mills Federation (ICMF) said on Wednesday.
Share of cotton fell to 80.23 percent in 1995/96 (April-March) from 81.14 percent a year ago, ICMF said in its 1995/96 annual report.
It did not give reasons for the fall.
Cotton consumption amounted to 2,184.07 million kilos in 1995/96, up from 1,959.64 million a year ago.
In 1993/94, cotton accounted for 83.19 percent of total fibre consumption, ICMF, which represents textile industry associations across India, said.
Viscose staple fibre accounted for 200.1 million kilos in 1995/96, up from 168.14 million a year ago.
Share of polyester staple fibre rose to 256.6 million kilos, up from 216.2 million in the year ago period, it said.
Acrylic staple fibre accounted for 71.79 million kilos in 1995/96, up from 58.34 million in the previous year.
Other miscellaneous fibres accounted for 9.64 million kilos, down from 12.96 million in the previous year, it said.
"The total consumption of man-made fibres during 1995/96 is provisionally placed at 538 million kilos compared to 456 million kilos in 1994/95, registering a growth of over 18 percent," ICMF said.
